titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Harold John Lutz Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Diane E. Kaplan

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:58

did.unittitle: Harold John Lutz papers

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers include correspondence, notes, and photographs which document Harold John Lutz's scholarly interests in the field of forestry, primarily soil science, ecology, and forest lands in Alaska.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Harold John Lutz Papers (MS 1723). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Harold John Lutz was born in Saline, Michigan, on August 11, 1900. He received his undergraduate education at Michigan State University and completed his master's degree and Ph.D. in forestry at Yale University in 1927 and 1933 respectively. Early in his career he worked for the United States Forest Service in Alaska and taught forestry at Penn State College. He joined the faculty of the Yale School of Forestry in 1933, where he taught until his retirement in 1968. He was a pioneer in the field of forest soils. Lutz died in 1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers include correspondence, notes, and photographs which document Harold John Lutz's scholarly interests in the field of forestry, primarily soil science, ecology, and forest lands in Alaska.
